author: @doctorbritain9632
text: I've always thought that Marx is one of the most easily debunked philosophers / economists that there is.  My feeling is that because his utopian goals are on the face of it "attractive" people blind themselves to the absurdities.

replies.author: @catdogfishdogcats
replies.text: It's because utopian means a dream, something to aspire to even though it is inherently unlikely or impossible.  It's the same as the dream of the lottery.  "If I work to earn this dollar, and spend it on a ticket, it might become 1 million dollars, and I will no longer have to work (Or be on welfare). It is based on emotional, not rationale, that's why it's successful.  The people who follow Marx don't have to critically analyze whether it would work, or where it's endpoints lead, they just have to believe in it, like a god, and work for it's ends in hope that like the Lotto Ticket it will give them what they want.

author: @pRopaaNS
text: Sounds like Marx rejects foundations of human nature as "animalistic", while having vision on some utopian humanistic characteristics, that are completely detached from such roots. Definetly not something that can ever lead to disaster.

replies.author: @CoffeeConnected
replies.text:
He seemed to believe that the human proclivity to want to achieve something as an individual and perhaps learn about yourself and become a better person by progressively bettering yourself had to be suppressed in favour of forcing people to be a slave to the collective.

He suggests that this is better for people but I never hear demonstrable evidence for why that would be. He just asserts that it is.
The only concrete evidence we have accumulated since Marx demonstrates the very worst outcomes for people imaginable.

replies.author: @magisterrleth3129
replies.text: It seems to me, Karl Marx was something of a hopeless optimist. I can't imagine being an atheist and simultaneously having a positive opinion of the human animal. I guess it goes to show Marx was wrong. Operating on the assumption that selfishness can be eliminated, communism could work. Unfortunately, humans are selfish, and the result is always a despotic autocrat.

replies.author: @pRopaaNS
replies.text: @magisterrleth3129  I think that Idea that humans are selfish by itself is a misunderstanding of human nature. "Selfishness" by itself is a loaded term, it assumes malicious intent.

replies.author: @magisterrleth3129
replies.text: @pRopaaNS I don't assume malicious intent, people are always acting in their self-interest in one way or another.

replies.author: @pRopaaNS
replies.text: @magisterrleth3129 Then why did Marx attempt to eliminate it, what's the reason to get rid of it? Why unfortunate that humans are selfish?

replies.author: @magisterrleth3129
replies.text: @pRopaaNS It's unfortunate that humans are selfish, because if they weren't, communism would have probably succeeded, and all the deaths it caused would not have happened. Marx wanted an end to selfishness in pursuit of a utopian dream, undoubtedly shaped by the time line of his life, where industrialization kicked off, and unionization hadn't by the time he died. He wanted to eliminate selfishness because that's the only way communism could work. I don't think selfishness is possible or even desirable to completely remove from the human equation, personally.

replies.author: @doochicka
replies.text: The thing I've come to understand is that ideologies that's aim is separate "Human" from "Animal" in the vain of finding some sort of Post-Animal human characteristics always end in Horrible disaster. Whether it's Fascism, Religious extremism, Socialism/Communism, Monarchy etc. Ideologies that try to see Human beings as anything other than just another animal tends to result in some of the most horrible atrocities committed in achieving those ends.

replies.author: @pRopaaNS
replies.text: @magisterrleth3129 If humans weren't selfish, then maybe it would have never come to this and we'd have gone extinct long time ago. The crux of what makes humanity prosper is that each of us are capable of taking care of themselves, which greatly reduces amount of problems for collective to work together to solve. Like Jordan Peterson says, first sort out your own room, before thinking about correcting the world. It is because so many of us have our lives in order that there is luxury of having spare resources to work on higher level problems.

replies.author: @cornbreadisbetterthanpizza6866
replies.text:
@CoffeeConnected Yes, and also he seems to suggest one of the worst parts of the economy is that the "capitalist" as he calls it runs the economy without the consent of the workers (and therefore steals the labor of the workers). His solution is for workers to create one giant collective governing force. The problem is that capitalists gain their place in the economy through voluntary interaction with workers (via free trade), and thus this collective government will become the new "capitalists".

Therefore, if Marx's dream of a dictatorship of the proletariat then it would result in what we have seen all throughout history. The economy is being controlled by the "capitalist" (using Marx's definition of a tyrant he controls the economy without the consent of the governed) he claims to hate. If the governing force is the same as the industrial force (Marx's dictatorship of the proletariat, or Mussolini's fascism) then that means there is no accountability, and thus it results in what was seen all throughout the history of Communism and fascism.

replies.author: @evensgrey
replies.text: @jerrodbates8480 This is some famous events, here.  Marx not only got (and lost) a number of jobs, he actually had a base income of something like a thousand pounds a year from his portion of his family's FACTORIES.  His increasingly heavy debts eventually left him, his wife, their four children, and the previously mentioned maid living in a 2-room apartment.  It was at this point he started having sex with the maid (the degree to which this was voluntary on the part of the maid is unclear, but technically from a Marxist point of view he DIDN'T have an economic hold on her, as he NEVER PAID HER ANYTHING), got her pregnant, and then insisted he wasn't the father and threw her out on the street with nothing but the clothes on her back.

replies.author: @jakell99
@differous01
replies.text:
The Marxian presupposition that history leads inevitably towards Communism is derived from Hegel and called Dialectic Materialism. It is a bowdlerised take on the Biblical tradition.
"To understand Marx psychologically one should use the following dictionary:
Yahweh = Dialectical Materialism 
The Messiah = Marx 
The elect = the proletariat
The Church = the Communist Party 
The second coming = the revolution 
Hell = punishment of the capitalist 
The millennium = the Communist Commonwealth.

The terms on the left give the emotional content of the terms on the right, and it is this emotional content, familiar to those who have had a Jewish or a Christian upbringing, that makes Marx‚Äôs eschatology credible.

A similar dictionary could be made for the Nazis, but their conceptions are more purely Old Testament, and less Christian than those of Marx and their Messiah is more analogous to the Macabees than to Christ.‚Äù
[Bertrand Russell‚Äôs ‚ÄòA History of Western Philosophy‚Äô]

author: @YinglisTheYinglet
text:
@LotusEaters
...there‚Äôs no cultural difference between the need to eat and drink before achieving security. it‚Äôs hard to be secure if you‚Äôre starving  or freezing...that‚Äôs a fact, what do you mean discredited?

the heirarchy of needs spilts the needs into 3 major groups, 

base needs: eat drink, warm, safety, ...

psychological needs: love, belonging, sense of self, prestige, esteem, ...

than the last one self accuallization, content that you were the best you could be.

Maslow‚Äôs heirarchy is a key area of study and widely used even outside of the sciences.

nor is it culturally specific to the west, Maslow wrote his heirarchy of needs after studying and engaging with the BlackFoot Nation.

he was criticized for misrepresenting the blackfoot world view and studying an exceedingly exceptional portion of the population outside of his study of the blackfoot. and for putting s3x too low on the heirarchy.

it has also been criticized for being somehow wacist.

and for degrading humanity by suggesting that human‚Äôs lower nature must be satisfied before the higher nature of humans can be achieved to make them distinct from animals.

in modern era the only real adjustment that was actually made was saying that the heirarchy is more flexible than full filling every last requirement before moving up a level.

you are objectively not safe if you‚Äôre starving, freezing, and... so not at least full filling some of these things does in fact make it objectively harder to reach anything from the level above it.

author: @martinm3474
text: Not as a slave, I think more like a serf.  West Europe moved away from that class of peasantry, while Russia held on to that level of class systems.  Many farm communities would work the land until the soil was spent, then pack up and move to unfarmed areas.  Catherine the Great brought in German farm communities with their improved soil management practices.  Once those German Russians left Russia worked to hold the farmers to the land, still with the land belonging to the crown.  Yes there is more to this conversation, just something to think about.

author: @lumeronswift
text: I wouldn't say that the Soviet Union collapsed very cleanly - the morality and morale of the USSR was collapsing for decades, resulting in a state of pseudo-anarchy for its final years, and while the actual topple of the system was perhaps less messy than other revolutions, that is because it was more of a resignation than a revolution. It also left massive power gaps that were very quickly filled by various mafias and shadow organizations... and Russia is still trying to overcome that transition (as are some of its child states, such as Belarus).

author: @lukeskirenko
text: To my understanding, the idea of history having a trajectory was interwoven with his economic analysis whereby capitalists, in an effort to out-compete each other, would replace human labour with machinery, which would create a growing underclass who were unable to afford the goods produced, leading to a 'crisis of capital', and in these circumstances a revolution would be inevitable. One would observe that this turned out not to be true, but also the current concern about technological unemployment actually concurs with the thesis. And this raises the question as to whether technological unemployment is actually likely to happen. I tend to think not, but I get the impression that many/most commentators regardless of political leaning tend to think it is a likely scenario/a real concern. But note, it wasn't simply a weird conviction that individuals generally aren't effectual in the unfolding of history in general, but rather that the economic structure of capitalism would lead to a falling profit for capitalists and an increase in the number of workers whose skills were outmoded by a replacement my machinery, which would lead to an unsustainable downwards pressure on wages for the proletariat. There was indeed a teleological supposition of a utopian replacement for the capitalist system, and utopianism at this juncture generally looks shonky.

author: @thepuzzlebox6620
text:
Competing for resources is the nature of all things. Marx treads rather carefully around this by waffling about the fact that we are superior to other lifeforms. Strictly controlling the distribution of luxury items is seen as the easiest means of establishing a heirachy that produces efficient collectivisation; one without dissent. This enables the state to organise large scale mobilisation projects near instantly by herding people around like cattle. 

Not taking advantage of humanities personality flaws leads to one thing: a socio-economic system that is more oppressive than Capitalism, not less.

author: @catdogfishdogcats
text: It's because utopian means a dream, something to aspire to even though it is inherently unlikely or impossible.  It's the same as the dream of the lottery.  "If I work to earn this dollar, and spend it on a ticket, it might become 1 million dollars, and I will no longer have to work (Or be on welfare). It is based on emotional, not rationale, that's why it's successful.  The people who follow Marx don't have to critically analyze whether it would work, or where it's endpoints lead, they just have to believe in it, like a god, and work for it's ends in hope that like the Lotto Ticket it will give them what they want.
